fields.description: Try testing for AccountAdmin persona and use that to control access to account mgmt features.
fields.summary: Test ability to AssumeRole in console for privileged roles

comments.body:
[~jloza], in our current permissions check, we try some IAM operations for accounts, users, etc. Those operations can succeed based on policies.
When I switch to checking the AccountAdministrator and ResourceAdministrator personas by trying to "AssumeRole", both fail, even for the eucalyptus/admin account. Are those personas currently assigned to any account and how can I check? euca/admin can't even check it's own policy list.
cc: [~sjones]

[~dkavanagh], there's a description of the intended usage for administrative roles here:

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/ARCH/Personas+Specification#PersonasSpecification-PrivilegedUsersandRoles

[~sjones], yes, I have looked at that. Perhaps a discussion would be helpful.
If we don't use eucalyptus/admin in the console anymore, I guess it doesn't matter if AssumeRole works for that account, but..
Current users who aren't using personas will need to switch if they simply rely on granting access to IAM commands to allow their account admins to create/manage users, etc. in the console.
It seems like there's a bootstrap process that can't be done with the console in that we cannot create an Allow policy to grant AssumeRole to any one of the individual accounts.

[~dkavanagh], there are examples of using policies for delegating access here:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_create_policy-examples.html

AFAIK, this policy is suitable. I'll try the euca2ools command gholms recommended to see what policy it generates.
[~gholms], does this make sense to you?
{code}
[root@d-30 ~]# euare-rolelistbypath 
arn:aws:iam::000672023265:role/eucalyptus/AccountAdministrator
arn:aws:iam::000672023265:role/eucalyptus/InfrastructureAdministrator
arn:aws:iam::000672023265:role/eucalyptus/ResourceAdministrator
[root@d-30 ~]# clcadmin-grant-admin-access -u one -a ui-test-acct-00 arn:aws:iam::000672023265:role/eucalyptus/ResourceAdministrator
error: Can not find role arn:aws:iam::000672023265:role/eucalyptus/ResourceAdministrator
{code}

update: this "worked"
[root@d-30 ~]# clcadmin-grant-admin-access -u one -a ui-test-acct-00 ResourceAdministrator

however, the console doesn't show any policy added to this user.

more digging. It looks like the tool adds a policy to the role that allows the given user to assume the role. hmm. In this case, only euca/admin can do this since that's the role owner. So, an account admin can never grant a ResourceAdministator role to one of his users.

Here's a question that just occurred to me. ([~sjones]), Can we not assume role with session creds? I know aws says it should work, but worth asking for Euca.
"Important: You cannot call AssumeRole by using AWS account credentials; access will be denied. You must use IAM user credentials or temporary security credentials to call AssumeRole."

[~sjones], If I recall from the meeting (and your notes), I needed both a role access policy (which I added via clcadmin-grant-admin-access) and a user policy in order for AssumeRole to work. The admin account cannot have the user policy. I've AssumeRole both as admin and an IAM user. Both listed in the assume role policy for the role. The user had an access policy in place. I will go look over aws docs to see if I can figure this out.
fwiw, looking this over to compare notes: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eutester/blob/d5443196127756e9f4bbe6e930ab85172b2fdaf7/eutester4j/com/eucalyptus/tests/awssdk/TestCannedRoles.java

Looking at the error response more closely, I do suspect STS creds cannot be used for AssumeRole: 2015-10-26 10:37:36,624 boto [DEBUG]:403 ForbiddenTemporary credentials forbidden for serviceTemporary credentials forbidden for service more info about request: 2015-10-26 10:37:36 DEBUG Host: tokens.a-09.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com 2015-10-26 10:37:36,142 boto [DEBUG]:Port: 8773 2015-10-26 10:37:36 DEBUG Port: 8773 2015-10-26 10:37:36,142 boto [DEBUG]:Params: {'Action': 'AssumeRole', 'RoleArn': 'arn:aws:iam::eucalyptus:role/eucalyptus/ResourceAdministrator', 'Version': '2012-12-01', 'RoleSessionName': 'ResourceAdmin'}

I've verified the fix works for an account admin.
I tested with an IAM user that had the AssumeRole access policy shown in an earlier comment, and that works as well.

The resource administrator has permissions to view IAM resources in non-system accounts (e.g. euare-* --as-account XXX), and to manage resources in non-system accounts (e.g. euca-describe-instances verbose, euca-terminate-instances i-XXXXXXXX). The resource administrator does not have permission to manage resources in the "eucalyptus" account or any other system account.

The AWS APIs typically expect the callers credentials to identify the account for a resource, so global (regional) identifiers must be used when deleting resources using the role (e.g. security group id rather than security group name) and resource creation is generally not possible. The available "management" functionality differs by service as does support for global identifiers that are eucalyptus specific (e.g. using the ELB DNS name for some ELB actions rather than the name)

[~jloza] I've been thinking more about this since it came up at the team meeting. It seems like (if I understand correctly), there are special functionalities that would need to be built for 2 of the 3 system roles.
 - AccountAdministrator: this could be like our current euca/admin login in that it has access to account mgmt functions.
 - InfrastructureAdministrator: not currently of use in the console until we support those functions.
 - ResourceAdministrator: It sounds like this role can be used to view resources across accounts and delete them. I haven't found that regular Describe (volumes in the case I tested) provides any additional resource visibility. It isn't clear we can make use of this in the console without further investigation (and possibly implementation).

I'll read more incase I need to revise this assessment.

[~dkavanagh], Yes, I thikn you're dead on. The customer workflow for account admin seems to really include some of the resource admin stuff, like deleting resources associated with an account. There may be back end work there, and the resource admin role may need to be combined with the account admin role to get alignment with actual customer use cases. 

There definitely may be additional back end work needed to make use of this feature. 

Also, customers may want to just define their own custom roles, and we'd need to be able to use those instead. Is that feasible? If the customer creates an additional role in the euca account, could the console discover and read those without additional work on the back end? Would this work better if there were APIs for those functions?

Thanks!

One comment on ResourceAdmin role first. I mentioned I wasn't able to view other volumes, but I suspect the "verbose" flag which we never really supported in the console would allow viewing those as it does for the euca/admin account.

About custom roles. Sadly, those aren't discoverable by just any user. Only the role owner can list those roles. I think this falls into the same category as shared buckets/objects. They are available, but not discoverable.
In my spike, I hard-coded the 3 fixed privileged roles. Going along with that, we could allow those to be configurable via console.ini, which would get around the "discoverability" problem.
[~dkavanagh], administrative roles in the eucalyptus account have well known ARNs so discovery/configuration should not be required.

[~sjones], we are getting some customer feedback that what they would actually use are custom roles they define themselves, rather than our canned roles. Not enough feedback to be turned into an actionable requirement yet, but data points nonetheless. That is why [~dkavanagh] was checking into that.
